description: From Middle English monchen, a variant of mocchen, mucchen ("to munch (food); chew audibly"; > Modern English dialectal mouch), probably imitative in origin (compare crunch). Compare also Old French mangier, mengier (“to bite; eat”), of similar sound and meaning.

entries.meaning: A location or restaurant where good eating can be expected.
examples: Sally is having a breakfast munch at her place!
We had a good munch at the chippy.

So once we had a shower with what only I can describe as a fitted garden hose with a broken head, ventured out to get some munch. We found a little restaurant, sat down and pretty much got told what we was [sic] having.

entries.meaning: (BDSM) A casual meeting for those interested in BDSM, usually at a restaurant.
(New York drill music, slang, derogatory) Someone who easily agrees to give oral sex. [popularized, if not invented, by Ice Spice from August 2022]

verbs.description: munch (third-person singular simple present munches, present participle munching, simple past and past participle munched)

entries.meaning: (often with "on") To chew with a grinding, crunching sound, and with the mouth closed.
examples: Jim was munching on a biscotti.

entries.meaning: To eat vigorously or with excitement.
examples: Watching old Bill munch his pancakes makes me hungry!
